Incident.Summary: two vehicle collision, dui arrest with cannabis personal use recovered

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
M-48 Body Worn Camera Operable, Front Facing Camera Not Operable

- Defendant: Purnell, Reginald Nathaniel 
- Defendant Date of Birth: 01/05/1981
- Time of Arrest: 0316
- DUI #: 23-023
- PBT: .000
-  Intoxometer: .000


TRAINING

- Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests (SFSTs) by the Maryland State Police and National Highway Safety Administration (NHTSA). 
- Certified to operate and administer the Preliminary Breath Test (PBT).

VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1)

On Thursday, February 23, 2023, at approximately 0253 hours, I, Trooper Gernatt #7248 of the JFK Highway Barrack, responded to a motor vehicle collision on southbound Interstate 95 in the area of the 67.8 mile-marker. The at fault vehicle, a silver Mitsubishi Mirage bearing Maryland registration "3EM3000", struck the rear of a black Toyota RAV4 while traveling in lane #2 in the area of the 68 mile-marker. Both vehicles came to rest on the right shoulder. I responded to check the welfare of all parties involved in the collision.

PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2)

I made contact with the operator of the silver Mitsubishi Mirage, who was identified as Reginald Nathaniel Purnell (B/F DOB 01/05/1981) of Maryland. While conversing with Purnell, I detected the strong odor of Marijuana emitting from the vehicle. I was able to recognize the odor of Marijuana from my training, knowledge, and experience as a Maryland State Trooper.I asked Purnell if she was driving. Purnell stated that she was driving, fell asleep, and struck the black Toyota RAV4. I asked Purnell if she smoked Marijuana, and she said that she does. I then asked when the last time she smoked, she advised that she did earlier the day before. Purnell's eyes were bloodshot, and she was only wearing one boot. I informed Purnell that I wanted to perform field sobriety tests, which she agreed to submit. 

PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3)

The evaluation was performed on the shoulder of Interstate 95 at the 67.8 mile-marker. The surface was dry, level, and free from any obvious debris. The lighting conditions were the streetlamps of Interstate 95. Purnell appeared to be in good physical condition and did not display any visible injuries, limps, or any limb ailments. 

Purnell mentioned that she may have issues balancing. 

HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS (6/6 CLUES OBSERVED)

The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus. The tip of my pen was the stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from Purnell's eyes. Purnell was instructed to look at the stimulus while keeping her head still, and to follow the stimulus with only her eyes. Purnell's eyes were equal in size, and showed equal tracking, and no resting the nystagmus was observed. I observed both of Purnell's pupils to be dilated. 

- Lack of Smooth Pursuit - Present in Both Eyes
- Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation - Present in Both Eyes
- Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees - Present in Both Eyes 
*Vertical Gaze Nystagmus - Not Present*

(NOTE: Both pupils were dilated)

WALK AND TURN (6/8 CLUES OBSERVED)

Prior to Purnell performing the test, I explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Purnell was instructed to place her right foot directly in front of her left foot, touching heel to toe. Purnell was then instructed to remain in that position until told to begin. Purnell was instructed to take nine (9) heel to toe steps in a straight line while looking down at her feet, counting out loud, while keeping her hands down at her sides. On the ninth step, Purnell was instructed to complete a series of small steps around her lead foot to her left to completely turn around. Purnell was then explained and demonstrated that the second series of nine (9) steps were to be completed in the same manner as the first series of steps. Purnell was instructed that once she began the test that she was not to stop walking until the test was completed, look down at her feet, count her steps out loud, and to keep her hands at her sides. I asked Purnell if she understood the test, she acknowledged that she did. (Footwear: blue boots).

Instructional Stage:

- Can't balance while listening to instructions

Walking Stage (1st Nine Steps):
- Doesn't touch heel-to-toe
- Steps off the line
- Uses arms for balance
- Incorrect number of steps

Turn:
- Improper turn

Walking Stage (2nd Nine Steps):
- Doesn't touch heel-to-toe
- Steps off the line

ONE LEG STAND (1/4 CLUES OBSERVED)

Prior to performing the test, I explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Purnell was instructed to stand with her feet together and hands down at her sides while the instructions were given and during the test. When instructed to start, Purnell was to raise the foot of her choice off the ground approximately 6 inches. Whle her leg was raised she was to keep her legs straight, watch her raised foot, and count out loud by the thousands (one thousand one, one thousand toe, one thousand three, etc.) and to continue until told to stop. I asked Purnell if she understood the test, and she acknowledged that she did. (Footwear: barefoot). 

Instructional Stage:

Balance and Counting Stage:

- Puts foot down

(NOTE: Purnell switched balancing foot)

PBT

Purnell submitted to a preliminary breath test administered by Trooper Schepleng #7461 with a .000 BrAC result. 

ARREST

Based on the following, I had reason to believe that Purnell was operating a motor vehicle while impaired by a controlled dangerous substance:

- Admitting to smoking Marijuana 
- Bloodshot eyes
- Dilated pupils
- At fault vehicle in a motor vehicle collision
- My observed signs of impairment as Purnell performed Standardized Field Sobriety Tests

I arrested Purnell at approximately 0316 hours for driving while impaired by a controlled dangerous substance (CDS). She was placed in the passenger seat of my patrol vehicle.

Due to the facts stated above, a probable cause search was conducted on the vehicle for the odor of Marijuana, which revealed:
- One plastic bag containing Marijuana 
- One blue and yellow bag labeled "Blue Dream Cannabis Flower" containing Marijuana 
- Total weight (including packaging): 8.8 grams

I was able to recognize the Marijuana due to my training, knowledge, and experience as a Maryland State Trooper. 

Purnell and the CDS were then transported to the Maryland State Police JFK Highway Barrack for processing. Purnell was read the audio version of the DR-15. Upon arrival to the barrack, Purnell signed the DR 15 agreeing to submit to the Intoximeter test, but refused to take a blood test. The CDS was processed and submitted (P-342069).

INTOXOMETER RESULTS 
.000

Purnell completed the Intoximeter test that morning at approximately 0334 hours. Purnell's breath result was a .000. 

Purnell was cited appropriately and released to a sober party: Weigele, Miranda Lynn (W/F 11/03/1994) of Maryland.

All events occurred in Baltimore County, Maryland.

Case closed.

IncidentProperty.Description: One heat sealed bag containing marijuana, one blue and yellow bag labeled Blue Dream Cannabis Flower containing marijuana

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
On 02/23/2023 at approximately 0600 hours, I (TFC Mott #6918) was coming on-duty for my scheduled early shift when I observed that a page had been sent for a DRE evaluation or the JFK Highway Barrack. As a certified Drug Recognition Expert, I contacted the JFK Highway Barrack to determine if a DRE had responded to assist. Upon speaking with Barrack personnel, I was advised that the suspect had invoked Miranda now did not wish to participe in a DRE evaluation. I conducted an interview of the arresting Trooper, Tpr Gernatt #7248. While interviewing Tpr Gernatt, I was advised that he was dispatched to a multiple vehicle collison. During the course of the investigation, he observed the operator of the at-fault vehicle to be showing signs of impairment in addition to admitting to consuming Marijuana prior to the collision. Tpr Gernatt stated that the driver was offered SFSTs and did not complete them to Tpr Gernatt satisfaction. Tpr. Gernatt also stated that Marijuana was recovered from the vehicle. Tpr Gernatt described the following general indicators of impairment:
Cannabis
  • Bloodshot eyes
  • Disoriented
  • Drowsy 
  • Odor of Marijuana 
  • Dialated pupils
  • Euphoria
  • Possession of Marijuana
  • Admitting to consuming Marijuana prior to collision
Based on my interview of Tpr Gernatt, reasonable grounds of CDS impairment was present. I authorized Tpr Gernatt to request a blood draw. The test was refused. I provided Tpr Gernatt a DR-23 to supplement his DR-15a.
